description: From green +‎ house ("house for growing greens"), in reference to the produce grown within.

entries.meaning: A building used to grow plants, particularly one with large glass windows or plastic sheeting to trap heat from sunlight even in intemperate seasons or climates.
(UK military slang, dated) The glass of a plane's cockpit.
examples: In the slang of the Royal Air Force man, the cockpit of his plane is the ‘pulpit’ or ‘office’, the glass covering over it the ‘greenhouse’.

entries.meaning: (medicine) A structure that shields the operating table to protect against bacteria.
examples: Figure 2.6 shows the diagram Charnley published of the airflow in the 'greenhouse'; it can be seen that reasonable downward unidirectional airflow was achieved close to the operating table.

entries.meaning: (climatology) A hot state in global climate.

verbs.description: greenhouse (third-person singular simple present greenhouses, present participle greenhousing, simple past and past participle greenhoused)

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To nurture in order to promote growth.
examples: It's almost impossible to make judgements when you're being playful – as by definition it's spontaneous activity – so your baby ideas get nurtured and greenhoused better.
